Wilson - Social Science Abstracts', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0022-0507&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'700'], u'eissns': [u'1471-6372'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'60'], u'issns': [u'0022-0507'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'\xa0 Geographic clustering in inventive activity has often been attributed to clustering in production. For the glass industry, we find that despite a general association between location of invention and production, there were significant deviations. Centers of production were not always centers of invention, and some of the most inventive areas, such as southern New England, had very limited production. We hypothesize that the growth of a market for technology facilitated a geographic division of labor between invention and commercial exploitation and stimulated inventive activity in places where there were institutions capable of mediating among inventors, suppliers of capital, and firms seeking new technologies. Reprinted with the permission of Cambridge University Press.', u'attribution': u''}]}

many scholars of international relations to contend that borders are eroding. My argument takes issue with this, suggesting that borders are not becoming increasingly meaningless; instead, some states are working to endow them with meaning in innovative ways. Specifically, I examine the trade disputes over culture industries during recent GATT and NAFTA talks to demonstrate that some states are shifting their attention from territorial borders to conceptual or invisible borders. Many governments support the removal of borders that serve as barriers to the movement of goods, services, capital, information, and, in some cases, people. Wilson - Social Science Abstracts', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0016-7398&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'255'], u'eissns': [u'1475-4959'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'166'], u'issns': [u'0016-7398'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'\xa0 The writer discusses the growth of the fruit export sector, land tenure, community organization, and female labor participation in the Guatulame area of northern Chile. She notes that the agro-export industry, particularly table grape production, has marginalized but not eliminated the small-scale, domestically-operated agricultural sector. She explores women\'s perceptions of their role in agriculture and how these relate to their identities as employees in the agro-export sector, which has benefited greatly from female labor. She investigates the multitude of ways in which women experience rapid changes in the agricultural sector and how these changes correlate to the preservation of more "traditional" practices and identities.', u'attribution': u''}]}

[u'269'], u'eissns': [u'1475-5661'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Enrichment Source', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'25'], u'issns': [u'0020-2754'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"Processes of globalization rework sovereignty as the ordering principle of the international political economy, creating new geographies of power. Such a reworking is most apparent offshore, a site where sovereignty is unbundled. The principle of sovereignty is maintained in the offshore financial centres' legal sovereignty but relinquished in terms of their fiscal powers. This unbundling articulates the state system and the capitalist economy. Such an unbundling is possible because sovereignty is based upon property rights. Changes in the practices and understandings of property rights change the meaning of sovereignty, altering the principle of differentiation which shapes the international political economy. In this way, the paradoxical marginality and centrality of offshoreness to the dynamics of the international political economy is explained.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"Processes of globalization rework sovereignty as the ordering principle of the international political economy, creating new geographies of power. Such a reworking is most apparent offshore, a site where sovereignty is unbundled. The principle of sovereignty is maintained in the offshore financial centres' legal sovereignty but relinquished in terms of their fiscal powers. This unbundling articulates the state system and the capitalist economy. Such an unbundling is possible because sovereignty is based upon property rights. Changes in the practices and understandings of property rights change the meaning of sovereignty, altering the principle of differentiation which shapes the international political economy. In this way, the paradoxical marginality and centrality of offshoreness to the dynamics of the international political economy is explained.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'Processes of globalization rework sovereignty as the ordering principle of the international political economy, creating new geographies of power. Such a reworking is most apparent offshore, a site where sovereignty is unbundled. The principle of sovereignty is maintained in the offshore financial centres legal sovereignty but relinquished in terms of their fiscal powers. This unbundling articulates the state system and the capitalist economy. Such an unbundling is possible because sovereignty is based upon property rights. Changes in the practices and understandings of property rights change the meaning of sovereignty, altering the principle of differentiation which shapes the international political economy. In this way, the paradoxical marginality and centrality of offshoreness to the dynamics of the international political economy is explained.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'In what he called "one of the most significant developments the diamond industry has seen since the 1930s," when his grandfather Ernest first took control of De Beers, former DeBeers chairman Harry Oppenheimer declared that the company was relinquishing its 112-year monopoly over the world\'s diamond supply. The old De Beers, referred to in the industry as "the Syndicate" for its seeming omnipotence and impenetrable facade, was dead. Was De Beers really changing at all? Or had it crafted a tale designed to seduce and appease worried antitrust regulators in the US and Europe - a tale that concealed the fact that the company\'s new initiative might make it as dominant in the future as it ever was?', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Asian Business & Reference'}]}

essay highlights how contemporary Muslim fundamentalists reduce Islam's rich and complex intellectual legacy to a set of authoritarian rules. The three branches of classical Islamic education--theology, jurisprudence, and ethics--are particularly targeted. The reductionist pattern applied to these areas is designed to eliminate both the scholarly space of inquiry and the room for individual reflection traditionally granted to its followers by Islamic religion. The essay ends with an analysis of the language used by Osama bin Laden in various documents over the last ten years that show how he has abused Islam's jurisprudential tradition to confer on him a convenient likeness of legality.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"This essay highlights how contemporary Muslim fundamentalists reduce Islam's rich and complex intellectual legacy to a set of authoritarian rules. The three branches of classical Islamic education-theology, jurisprudence, and ethics-are particularly targeted. The reductionist pattern applied to these areas is designed to eliminate both the scholarly space of inquiry and the room for individual reflection traditionally granted to its followers by Islamic religion. The essay ends with an analysis of the language used by Osama bin Laden in various documents over the last ten years that show how he has abused Islam's jurisprudential tradition to confer on him a convenient likeness of legality. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]", u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}]}

u'databases': [{u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/politicalscience/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'M2L', u'source_types': [u'Aggregation Database'], u'name': u'ProQuest Political Science', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'1531-426X'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'Mercosur has survived several crises by resorting to presidential diplomacy, but it risks becoming an empty shell unless member states work to coordinate macroeconomic policies. Its survival depends on the outcome of domestic political struggles in Brazil and Argentina and on the harmonization of exchange-rate policies between the two countries. This article examines the Argentine-Brazilian "trade wars" provoked by successive devaluations of tile Brazilian currency, aggravated in 2001 by the Argentine economic crisis. The social explosion in Argentina in December 2001 showed that domestic actors can successfully challenge proglobalization policies. To consolidate, Mercosur will have to address the democratic deficit while building supranational institutions and an effective dispute-settlement system.', u'attribution': u'EconLit'}, {u'abstract': u'Mercosur has survived several crises by resorting to presidential diplomacy, but it risks becoming an empty shell unless member states work to coordinate macroeconomic policies. Its survival depends on the outcome of domestic political struggles in Brazil and Argentina and on the harmonization of exchange-rate policies between the two countries. This article examines the Argentine-Brazilian "trade wars" provoked by successive devaluations of the Brazilian currency, aggravated in 2001 by the Argentine economic crisis. The social explosion in Argentina in December 2001 showed that domestic actors can successfully challenge proglobalization policies. To consolidate, Mercosur will have to address the democratic deficit while building supranational institutions and an effective dispute-settlement system.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'Mercosur has survived several crises by resorting to presidential diplomacy, but it risks becoming an empty shell unless member states work to coordinate macroeconomic policies. Its survival depends on the outcome of domestic political struggles in Brazil and Argentina and on the harmonization of exchange-rate policies between the two countries. This article examines the Argentine-Brazilian "trade wars" provoked by successive devaluations of the Brazilian currency, aggravated in 2001 by the Argentine economic crisis. The social explosion in Argentina in December 2001 showed that domestic actors can successfully challenge proglobalization policies. To consolidate, Mercosur will have to address the democratic deficit while building supranational institutions and an effective dispute-settlement system. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}]}

of historical writing in the colonial period, Russell-Wood discusses the growing movement in the 19th and 20th centuries to preserve documents in libraries, archives, and museums in Brazil.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'This article draws attention to archival research by Brazilian historians in Portugal and Brazil and the fruits of these labors in monographs, dissertations, and articles. Following a survey of historical writing in the colonial period, this essay discusses the growing movement in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries to preserve documents in libraries, archives, and museums in Brazil. The existence of such institutions spurred divulgation of manuscript collections through journals and published transcriptions of documents. The essay then traces Brazilian historiography in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries as well as Brazilian responses to new trends in historical writing in the 1960s. A survey of archives consulted by scholars of colonial Brazil provides the background for the main section, which uses case studies to demonstrate how Brazilian historians have used these depositories. Scholarship published between 1983 and 1999 is emphasized. The intensive use of manuscript collections and the high quality of publications testify to the vitality of studies by Brazilian scholars of colonial Brazil.', u'attribution': u''}]}

[u'Index Database'], u'name': u'MEDLINE (Ovid)', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0023-8791'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"\xa0 An analysis of data from Mexico's Encuesta Nacional de la Dinamica Demografica, the US Census, and the Mexican Migration Project revealed some continuities and changes in the profile of Mexican migration to the US.", u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u"This research note examines continuities and changes in the profile of Mexican migration to the United States using data from Mexico's Encuesta Nacional de la Dinamica Demografica, the U.S. Census, and the Mexican Migration Project. Our analysis generally yields a picture of stability over time. Mexico- U.S. migration continues to be dominated by the states of Western Mexico, particularly Guanajuato, Jalisco, and Michoacan, and it remains a movement principally of males of labor-force age. As Mexico has urbanized, however, out-migration has come to embrace urban as well as rural workers; and as migrant networks have expanded, the flow has become less selective with respect to education. Perhaps the most important change detected was an acceleration in the rate of return migration during the early 1990s, reflecting the massive legalization of the late 1980s.", u'attribution': u''}]}

u'8BH', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'EconLit', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0002-9246'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'The paper discusses the role of uncertainty in economic sociology, aiming to clarify some controversial issues in the related literature. Initially, some conceptual remarks are made about the relation between economic sociology, neoclassical economics, and rational choice theory. Next, in light of the existing literature on uncertainty and economic sociology, we distinguish between complexity and different types of uncertainty. We also identify different versions of the maximization hypothesis and examine their relations to the different types of uncertainty. Then we defend a concept of fundamental uncertainty that emphasizes the role of institutions. A theory that combines fundamental uncertainty and institutions should emphasize not only the existence of behavior in accordance with institutions, but also the possibility of creative, bold, unconventional behavior, discussed next, as people may use the knowledge provided by institutions to go against the tide. Finally, we suggest that the primary distinction should be that between approaches to economic issues, not between disciplines.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'. u'publisher': u'Elsevier Ltd', u'end_pages': [u'65'], u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0968-8080&client=summon', u'PubMed', u'sequence': 1}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://ovidsp.ovid.com/ovidweb.cgi?T=JS&MODE=ovid&PAGE=main&NEWS=N&D=medf', u'dbid': u'CVF', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'MEDLINE (Ovid)', u'sequence': 2}], u'issns': [u'0968-8080'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'South Africa\'s first democratic government passed the Domestic Violence Act (DVA) into law in 1998 as part of local and international commitments to protecting the human rights of women. Although the Act was welcomed as groundbreaking legislation, delays in implementing it led to increasing frustration. This paper describes an advocacy campaign conducted by the Soul City Institute for Health and Development Communication in partnership with the National Network on Violence against Women, to ensure the effective implementation of the DVA. Lessons from the campaign stress the importance of coalition building to draw on diverse strengths, and the use of a combination of advocacy tools, including lobbying, media advocacy and social mobilisation to achieve campaign goals. Given the critical role NGOs dealing with victims/survivors of domestic violence and the justice system played in lobbying for change and drafting the new law, their exclusion from the implementation process was ironic. While many advocacy efforts focus on the development of policy and legislation, ongoing efforts are needed to ensure effective implementation, the commitment of adequate resources and monitoring to identify gaps and propose new solutions. Our experience highlights the important role of policy advocates in connecting the multiple streams at play in the policy and legislative arena. /// Le premier gouvernement d\xe9mocratique de l\'Afrique du Sud a adopt\xe9 la Domestic Violence Act en 1998 dans le cadre de ses engagements locaux et internationaux en faveur de la protection des droits fondamentaux des femmes. Bien que la Loi ait \xe9t\xe9 salu\xe9e comme un progr\xe8s d\xe9cisif, les retards dans son application ont suscit\xe9 une frustration croissante. Le Soul City Institute for Health and Development Communication a men\xe9, en partenariat avec le R\xe9seau national sur la violence \xe0 l\'\xe9gard des femmes, une campagne d\'information pour garantir une application efficace de la Loi. Les le\xe7ons de la campagne montrent qu\'il est important d\'\xe9tablir des coalitions pour profiter de diverses forces, et d\'utiliser un assortiment d\'outils de plaidoyer, notamment les groupes de pression, les m\xe9dias et la mobilisation sociale, pour atteindre les objectifs fix\xe9s. L\'ironie veut que malgr\xe9 le r\xf4le essentiel que les ONG s\'occupant des victimes de la violence familiale et le syst\xe8me de justice ont jou\xe9 pour amener le changement et faire adopter la nouvelle loi, ils aient \xe9t\xe9 exclus du processus d\'application. Alors que beaucoup d\'activit\xe9s de plaidoyer portent sur l\'\xe9laboration de politiques et de l\xe9gislations, des efforts sont requis pour garantir une application efficace, l\'engagement de ressources suffisantes et un suivi destin\xe9 \xe0 identifier les lacunes et proposer des solutions. Notre exp\xe9rience met en lumi\xe8re le r\xf4le important des d\xe9fenseurs politiques pour mettre en rapport les multiples courants qui s\'exercent dans l\'ar\xe8ne politique et l\xe9gislative /// En 1998, el primer gobierno democr\xe1tico de Sud\xe1frica aprob\xf3 la Ley de Violencia Dom\xe9stica (LVD) como parte de los compromisos dom\xe9sticos e internacionales de proteger los derechos humanos de las mujeres. Si bien se recibi\xf3 esta ley emblem\xe1tica con benepl\xe1cito, atrasos en su implementaci\xf3n llevaron a una creciente frustraci\xf3n. Este art\xedculo describe una campa\xf1a dirigida a asegurar la implementaci\xf3n efectiva de la LVD, conducida por el Instituto de Salud y Comunicaci\xf3n para el Desarrollo "Soul City". Los aprendizajes de esta campa\xf1a ponen hincapi\xe9 en la importancia de construir alianzas y hacer uso de una combinaci\xf3n de modalidades de activismo para lograr las metas de la campa\xf1a, las cuales incluyen el cabildeo, el trabajo con los medios de comunicaci\xf3n y la movilizaci\xf3n social. Aunque las ONG jugaron un papel cr\xedtico en torno al trato de las v\xedctimas de violencia dom\xe9stica, y el sistema judicial hizo lo propio al abogar a favor del cambio y redactar la nueva ley, result\xf3 ir\xf3nica su exclusi\xf3n del proceso de implementaci\xf3n. Mucho activismo est\xe1 enfocado en la elaboraci\xf3n de pol\xedticas y legislaci\xf3n, pero se precisan esfuerzos continuos para asegurar la implementaci\xf3n efectiva de las mismas, la asignaci\xf3n de recursos adecuados, y el monitoreo para identificar faltas y proponer soluciones nuevas. Nuestra experiencia subraya el papel importante de quienes promuevan pol\xedticas a favor de ligar las m\xfaltiples corrientes en juego en la esfera pol\xedtica y legislativa.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"South Africa's first democratic government passed the Domestic Violence Act (DVA) into law in 1998 as part of local and international commitments to protecting the human rights of women. Although the Act was welcomed as groundbreaking legislation, delays in implementing it led to increasing frustration. This paper describes an advocacy campaign conducted by the Soul City Institute for Health and Development Communication in partnership with the National Network on Violence against Women, to ensure the effective implementation of the DVA. Lessons from the campaign stress the importance of coalition building to draw on diverse strengths, and the use of a combination of advocacy tools, including lobbying, media advocacy and social mobilisation to achieve campaign goals. Given the critical role NGOs dealing with victims/survivors of domestic violence and the justice system played in lobbying for change and drafting the new law, their exclusion from the implementation process was ironic. While many advocacy efforts focus on the development of policy and legislation, ongoing efforts are needed to ensure effective implementation, the commitment of adequate resources and monitoring to identify gaps and propose new solutions. Our experience highlights the important role of policy advocates in connecting the multiple streams at play in the policy and legislative arena.", u'attribution': u'MEDLINE'}]}

This paper first examines this shift in policy assumptions at the EU level and goes on to argue that there are real limits to the pursuit of a full adult worker model based on the commodification of care. In respect of gender equality, this in turn raises the issue of the terms and conditions on which such a shift in policy assumptions are made, particularly about the valuing and sharing of the unpaid work of care. The final part of the paper examines the possibilities offered by the capabilities approach of addressing these issues.', u'attribution': u'EconLit'}, {u'abstract': u'There is evidence that policy-makers in most Western welfare states are moving towards a new set of assumptions about the contributions that men and women make to families, based on an adult worker model. This paper first examines this shift in policy assumptions at the EU level and goes on to argue that there are real limits to the pursuit of a full adult worker model based on the commodification of care. In respect of gender equality, this in turn raises the issue of the terms and conditions on which such a shift in policy assumptions are made, particularly about the valuing and sharing of the unpaid work of care. The final part of the paper examines the possibilities offered by the capabilities approach of addressing these issues.', u'attribution': u''}]}

social inequality has not been resolved largely because the issues have not been adequately formulated. This dichotomy is abandoned and explicit models of five approaches to explaining inequality are presented.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u"The long debate between functional and conflict theories of social inequality has not been resolved largely because the issues have been inadequately formulated. This paper largely abandons this dichotomy and presents explicit models of five approaches to explaining inequality. These are then synthesized into a common framework. It is shown that stratification literature as divergent as status attainment models, the Davis-Moore theory, power elite studies, Lenski's evolutionary theory, Habermas' analysis of distorted communications, and world-systems theory can be subsumed under the framework.", u'attribution': u''}]}

u'publisher': u'Cass', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0306-6150&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'1'], u'eissns': [u'1743-9361'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Enrichment Source', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'25'], u'issns': [u'0306-6150'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'Migrant labour in Southern Africa is associated historically with rural poverty and a high incidence of women-headed households. Poverty alleviation approaches to social policy ask whether in this context rural women-headed households are poorer than those headed by men. Ample research from the region shows that the answer is not always, a finding once more confirmed here in an analysis of Botswana. This case suggests, however, that the wrong question is being asked. The incidence of both women-headed households and rural poverty has increased with the polarisation of agrarian production and the exclusionary restructuring of the migrant labour system. We need to ask not whom to target, but what should be done when capital no longer needs the labour that it pulled from rural households over so many generations.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'publisher': u'Taylor & Francis Group', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0305-7070&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'277'], u'eissns': [u'1465-3893'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Enrichment Source', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'27'], u'issns': [u'0305-7070'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'The age pattern of fertility in a rural area of South Africa under health and demographic surveillance (Agincourt subdistrict) was investigated over the 1992-1997 period. The total fertility rate (number of children born, on average, to the women of this population) averaged 3.3 over the period, a major drop from earlier estimates in the same area (6.0 in 1970-1974). Age-specific fertility rates showed an atypical bimodal pattern composed of two components of similar magnitude: premarital fertility (ages 12-26) and marital fertility (ages 15-49). These two components demonstrate a peak of premarital fertility (around age 18-20 years) and a peak of marital fertility (around age 28-30 years). Premarital fertility accounted for 21 per cent of all births, and for 47 per cent of births to women aged 12-26 years. Thus, in the Northern Province of South Africa at least, premarital fertility is a significant demographic and social phenomenon that contributes to a deeper understanding of both teenage and adolescent pregnancy. In addition, it extends these two concepts to cover the important social and economic consequences of pregnancies among those aged 12 to 26 years. The paper discusses a number of qualitative studies that provide insight into the social and cultural context of marriage, fertility and sexuality in the area. It also considers how this pattern of very high premarital fertility appears to reflect a lack of contraception before the first birth, especially among adolescents, a low prevalence of abortion, and a high contraceptive prevalence thereafter. This finding calls for a reorientation of the family planning policy, which so far has targeted married women and women after their first pregnancy, but has failed to address the contraceptive needs of young women before the first pregnancy, especially adolescents.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0305-7070&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'349'], u'eissns': [u'1465-3893'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Enrichment Source', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'27'], u'issns': [u'0305-7070'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"Contemporary demographic discourse and population policies in southern Africa tend to focus upon the positive value of low, and ever lowering, total fertility rates. In Botswana, statistics suggest a high rate of extramarital fertility and a rapidly increasing HIV infection rate. While these represent visible problems for demographers and policy makers, infertility - a significant problem for many Batswana - remains 'invisible' in much of demographic discourse. This paper suggests that while infertility may be an invisible demographic variable, it is particularly significant in the lives of the people of northern Botswana and it can be a useful lens through which to view cultural constructions of gender and health. For many women in Botswana, infertility, the apparent inability to bear children, is a serious social and physiological concern and one that is intricately tied to local perceptions of contraceptives and witchcraft, for example. In addition, with large scale migration by men to other areas of southern Africa, women find themselves confronted with various economic concerns and the necessity to negotiate childbearing in that context. It is argued that a more social and ethnographic understanding of the importance of fertility can lead to a better understanding of why some population policies are not particularly efficacious. This paper is based upon ethnographic fieldwork in northern Botswana and represents an attempt to synthesise anthropological and demographic approaches to the concept of fertility by examining the often overlooked variable of infertility.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'This paper suggests that while infertility may be an invisible demographic variable, it is particularly significant in the lives of the people of northern Botswana and it can be a useful lens through which to view cultural constructions of gender and health.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'Attempts to synthesize anthropological and demographic approaches to the concept of fertility by examining the often overlooked variable of infertility. Notes that while it may be an invisible demographic variable, it is particularly significant in the lives of the people of northern Botswana and it can be a useful lens through which to view cultural constructions of gender and health. Argues that a more social and ethnographic understanding of the importance of fertility can lead to a better understanding of why some population policies are not particularly efficacious.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"Contemporary demographic discourse and population policies in southern Africa tend to focus upon the positive value of low, and ever lowering, total fertility rates. In Botswana, statistics suggest a high rate of extramarital fertility and a rapidly increasing HIV infection rate. While these represent visible problems for demographers and policy makers, infertility - a significant problem for many Batswana - remains 'invisible' in much of demographic discourse. This paper suggests that while infertility may be an invisible demographic variable, it is particularly significant in the lives of the people of northern Botswana and it can be a useful lens through which to view cultural constructions of gender and health. For many women in Botswana, infertility, the apparent inability to bear children, is a serious social and physiological concern and one that is intricately tied to local perceptions of contraceptives and witchcraft, for example. In addition, with large scale migration by men to other areas of southern Africa, women find themselves confronted with various economic concerns and the necessity to negotiate childbearing in that context. It is argued that a more social and ethnographic understanding of the importance of fertility can lead to a better understanding of why some population policies are not particularly efficacious. This paper is based upon ethnographic fieldwork in northern Botswana and represents an attempt to synthesise anthropological and demographic approaches to the concept of fertility by examining the often overlooked variable of infertility.", u'attribution': u''}]}

32', u'thumbnail_small': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/sc.gif&issn=0021-8499&client=summon', u'fulltext_link': u'http://tufts.summon.serialssolutions.com/2.0.0/link/0/eLvHCXMw3V1LS8NAEF5sBfEiahVfhVz0UqJJNk-olVhbPAnSKt7CvoJCTUqb_n9nmmeL4N3bMgk5zLc7j818M4RQ69bQt2wCjSFSwPCVw3HyHWHaMZceGE_YYg5bA__64k7e6fjJf6xnYday_wA8mNekJ1OF3ZryYct4G_CJU4bgLOesyGs6BouwLBtKZwsm8Mq8VzDVfg1XGx8ry_Ua16ALVlcfyoJV51RVUuADcsPn4T_ewAialjFvJFLsAKdh5gorlzvM4n5yo5X1loupCv-G4QeS1w0kCEH2Z99gg_Nv-SWye5Xob5MWaUF-hTzMUVg5VMtwnI0EoFFztw4DpofkoFCIFuZ6PyI7KjkmeyV9oEPSPh8gAv07PtBgjUCU6wYepQhh0Vii5bCg9AHFobbGpnwrjbUSouq7gBSuT8h0PJoOn_ViqIU-h8hIl3AGhGsLSYXnmWagICFmkFS7LOAcUk_XZq6wqLDNOIBs3GGMup5ShuSuEoYV01PSTtJEnRHNlMh-NSWkR8z2uM1pID1DBLaIjZiZwTnplCqL5GwW-a4PwTeIu6i-aJ53M4m2Ibn44_kl2a930BVpZ4uV6pLdbBVnyx9fxjom', u'publisher': u'Advertising Research Foundation', u'end_pages': [u'32'], u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0021-8499&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'19'], u'eissns': [u'1740-1909'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'35'], u'issns': [u'0021-8499'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'This paper attempts to find characteristics of product categories, brands, and ad copy that lead to either increased or decreased effectiveness of advertising spending on advertisement awareness, brand awareness, or purchase intentions, as measured through tracking data. Data were obtained for a total of 29 separate campaigns, with each campaign providing between 2 and 25 observations, some for multiple target audiences. Because the data available for each campaign often covered different dependent and moderating variables, leading to the loss of large amounts of data, the analysis was restricted to that subset of the data and those variables where enough data were available to allow analysis. Usable data were available for 224 observations for ad awareness, 230 for brand awareness, and 159 for purchase intentions, before a few outliers were excluded. Using a metaanalysis of such data for frequently purchased packaged goods, the authors found that advertising spending has a greater effect on awareness for less-visible brands in growing product categories and a greater effect on purchase intentions when the advertisement features a new strategy or new copy or new benefits; when the brand has significant trade promotion support; when the advertising copy is not "soft sell"; and when the brand is not already a "declining brand." These results are generally consistent with earlier field studies examining the effects of advertising weight on sales.', u'attribution': u'Communication Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 Characteristics of product categories, brands, and ad copy that lead to either increased or decreased effectiveness of advertising spending on ad awareness, brand awareness, or purchase intentions, are measured through tracking data. Using a meta-analysis of such data for frequently purchased packaged goods, it is shown that advertising spending has a greater effect on awareness for less-visible brands in growing product categories and a greater effect on purchase intentions when the ad features a new strategy or new copy or new benefits; when the brand has significant trade promotion support; when the ad copy is not "soft sell"; and when the brand is not already a "declining brand." These results are generally consistent with earlier field studies examining the effects of advertising weight on sales.', u'attribution': u'ABI/INFORM Select'}]}

u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0021-8499&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'28'], u'eissns': [u'1740-1909'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'34'], u'issns': [u'0021-8499'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'\xa0 A justification for an appropriate level of media spending is provided, and a method that shows at what expenditure level the best return is achieved and when the efficiency of advertising media spending is maximized is presented. To determine the optimal level of advertising media spending, there are 3 financial objectives: 1. maximizing advertising profitability, 2. maximizing advertising productivity, and 3. maximizing advertising return on investment. In addition, a practical, managerial tool for determining optimal media expenditure levels must be produced by determining how cost and effectiveness relate to GRPs. Media-planning models combined with the judgment of the media planner can provide good estimates of the cost and effectiveness of particular GRP levels. The standard application of these models may be used to obtain the 4 model constants needed to obtain the optimal GRP level.', u'attribution': u'ABI/INFORM Select'}, {u'abstract': u'The purpose of this paper is to adopt the view that advertising is an investment and to propose a simple formula for calculating the level of media spending that maximizes the return on investment. The information that must be supplied for the calculation is commonly available to media planners, and the authors express the optimal expenditure level in terms that are meaningful to a media planner. This approach may also please the cost cutters, because it often implies that not all of the media budget should be spent. The authors conclude that, since media budgets still rely primarily on ad hoc rules of thumb that have no solid basis, advertising is too often the defenseless target of ruthless corporate cost cutters. If advertising is viewed, instead, as an investment, and if the level of media spending that maximizes return on investment can be calculated, then a more appropriate level of media spending may be retained. This paper shows how a set of reasonable assumptions results in a simple formula for selling the optimal media expenditure level. The expenditure level is optimal in that it maximizes efficiency (defined as effectiveness divided by media expenditure) and also maximizes the return on advertising investment. Required inputs for the calculation are all of the sort that can be supplied easily by a modern media planner.', u'attribution': u'Communication Abstracts'}]}

u'start_pages': [u'311'], u'eissns': [u'1939-1315'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'38'], u'issns': [u'0022-3514'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'The meaning that persons attribute to environments is divided into perceptual cognitive meaning and affective meaning. Affective meaning is then conceptualized as a 2-dimensional bipolar space that can be defined by 8 variables falling in the following circular order around the perimeter: pleasant (arbitrarily set at 0\xb0), exciting (45\xb0), arousing (90\xb0), distressing (135\xb0), unpleasant (180\xb0), gloomy (225\xb0), sleepy (270\xb0), and relaxing (315\xb0, which is thus 45\xb0 from pleasant). Alternatively, the same space can be defined by 2 orthogonal bipolar dimensions of pleasant-unpleasant and arousing-sleepy, or equally well by exciting-gloomy and distressing-relaxing. Reliable verbal scales (based on data from 241 Ss) for these 8 variables were developed and shown to approximate the proposed theoretical structure. (28 ref)', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 The meaning that persons attribute to environments is divided into perceptual cognitive meaning and affective meaning. Affective meaning is then conceptualized as a 2-dimensional bipolar space that can be defined by 8 variables falling in the following circular order around the perimeter: pleasant (arbitrarily set at 0|), exciting (45|), arousing (90|), distressing (135|), unpleasant (180|), gloomy (225|), sleepy (270|), and relaxing (315|, which is thus 45| from pleasant). Alternatively, the same space can be defined by 2 orthogonal bipolar dimensions of pleasant-unpleasant and arousing-sleepy, or equally well by exciting-gloomy and distressing-relaxing. Reliable verbal scales (based on data from 241 Ss) for these 8 variables were developed and shown to approximate the proposed theoretical structure. (28 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved)', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0742-6046&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'361'], u'eissns': [u'1520-6793'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'14'], u'issns': [u'0742-6046'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"A large-scale cross-sectional field study is presented of the effect of store environment on consumer emotions and the resulting influence on aspects of consumer behavior with actual shopping behavior used as an example. Cast into a stimulus-organism-response framework, the results suggest that a consumer's emotions can be a mediating factor in the purchase process. How store environment and emotional states may influence various dimensions of purchase behavior is identified and explored. This research confirms that although cognitive factors may largely account for store selection and for most planned purchases within the store, the environment in the store and the emotional state of consumers may be important determinants of purchase behavior. This research has many pragmatic applications because pleasure was associated with the amount of money spent and affinity for the store, whereas arousal was associated with money spent in the store, time spent in the store, and the number of items purchased in the store.", u'attribution': u'ABI/INFORM Select'}, {u'abstract': u"This article presents a large-scale cross-sectional field study of the effect of store environment on consumer emotions and the resulting influence on aspects of consumer behavior, with actual shopping behavior used as an example. Cast into the stimulus-organism-response framework, the results suggest that a consumer's emotions can be a mediating factor in the purchase process. In this study, the authors identify and explore how store environment and emotional states may influence various dimensions of purchase behavior. This research confirms that, although cognitive factors may largely account for store selection and for most planned purchases within the store, the environment in the store and the emotional state of consumers may be important determinants of purchase behavior. This research has many pragmatic applications, because pleasure was associated with the amount of money spent and affinity for the store, whereas arousal was associated with money spent, time spent, and the number of items purchased in the same store.", u'attribution': u'Communication Abstracts'}]}

Reidel Publishing Company', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0303-8300&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'1'], u'eissns': [u'1573-0921'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Index Database', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'1'], u'databases': [{u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/socialservices/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'7U3', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Social Services Abstracts', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0303-8300'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"This report presents the current status of a series of studies oriented toward the assessment of perceived life quality. The conceptual model proposes that a person's overall sense of life quality is understandable as a combination of affective responses to life 'domains', which are of two types - role situations and values. Over 100 items used to measure a wide variety of domains and 28 items assessing perceived overall life quality are presented. Various subsets of these items were used in interviews with several representative samples of American adults. Based on these data the domain items were grouped into a smaller number of semi-independent clusters which were internally stable across 10 different subgroups of the respondents and whose interrelationships were highly replicable in independent national samples. A series of analyses, some replicated in more than one survey showed: (1) an additive combination of 12 selected domains explained 50-60% of the variance in an index of overall life quality, (2) neither other domains nor several social characteristic variables contributed additional explanatory power, (3) this level of explanation was achieved in each of 22 subgroups of the population, and (4) additive combinations of domains worked as well as more complicated combinations.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'The current status of a series of studies oriented toward the assessment of perceived life quality is presented. The conceptual model proposes that a person\'s overall sense of life quality is understandable as a combination of affective responses to life "domains," which are of two types -- role situations & values. Over 100 items used to measure a wide variety of domains & 28 items assessing perceived overall life quality are presented. Various subsets of these items were used in interviews with representative samples of US adults. Based on these data the domain items were grouped into a smaller number of semiindependent clusters. Results of a series of analyses were: (1) a combination of 12 domains explained 50%-60% of the variance in an index of overall life quality; (2) neither other domains nor social characteristic variables contributed additional explanatory power; (3) this level of explanation was achieved in all 22 population subgroups; & (4) additive combinations of domains worked as well as more complicated combinations. 11 Figures. Modified HA.', u'attribution': u'Social Services Abstracts'}]}

Reidel Publishing Company', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0303-8300&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'73'], u'eissns': [u'1573-0921'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Index Database', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'6'], u'databases': [{u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/socialservices/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'7U3', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Social Services Abstracts', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0303-8300'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"Data from a national survey of 1,297 American conducted by F. M. Andrews & S. B. Withey (Social Indicators of Well-Being: Americans' Perceptions of Life Quality, New York: Plenum, 1976) & from national parallel surveys of approximately 1,000 Rs in each of 8 European nations, conducted by the European Economic Community in May, 1976, covering 11 questions of comparable content present in both sets of responses, are analyzed through smallest space analysis to determine the structure of subjective well-being. These structures can be used to determine breadth of coverage & degree of redundancy of social indicators of perceived well-being. Structures in all these countries are basically similar, but the European countries are more similar to each other than any is to the US. Results suggest that comparative research on subjective well-being is feasible within this group of nations. 6 Figures. Modified HA.", u'attribution': u'Social Services Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'The structure of subjective well-being is analyzed by multidimensional mapping of evaluations of life concerns. For example, one finds that evaluations of Income are close to (i.e., relatively strongly related to) evaluations of Standard of living, but remote from (weakly related to) evaluations of Health. These structures show how evaluations of life components fit together and hence illuminate the psychological meaning of life quality. They can be useful for determining the breadth of coverage and degree of redundancy of social indicators of perceived well-being. Analyzed here are data from representative sample surveys in Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Great Britain, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, and the United States (each N \u2248 1000). Eleven life concerns are considered, including Income, Housing, Job, Health, Leisure, Neighborhood, Transportation, and Relations with other people. It is found that structures in all of these countries have a basic similarity and that the European countries tend to be more similar to one another than they are to USA. These results suggest that comparative research on subjective well-being is feasible within this group of nations.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'publisher': u'Kluwer Academic Publishers', u'end_pages': [u'328'], u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0303-8300&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'303'], u'eissns': [u'1573-0921'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Index Database', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'38'], u'issns': [u'0303-8300'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'\xa0 A study attempts to group 173 different domains names derived from the literature under seven heading as used by the Comprehensive Quality of Life Scale.', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Health Management'}, {u'abstract': u'The two basic approaches to the definition and measurement of subjective quality of life are examined in this article: one sees the construct as a single, unitary entity; the other considers it to be composed of discrete domains. Early examples of the first approach are analysed. The second approach is more recently used but problems with the number of domains are identified. Empirical support for the use of five domains is discussed. These domains which are regarded of most importance to the quality of life of respondents are: emotional well-being; health; social and family connections; material wealth or well being; and work or other form of productive activity. Additional domains of safety and community are considered. The methodology of the studies supplying the data for this research is analysed and the calculation of the Comprehensive Quality of Life Scale (ComQol) domain values is examined. Standardisation effects on normative data, general population domain values and other putative domains are reviewed. A discussion of the results is provided and concerns issues such as: the selection of articles for the study; the sorting of reported domains into the seven ComQol categories; and whether the original domain names have been validly sorted. Substantive support is provided for the idea that life satisfaction can be efficiently and comprehensively measured through the seven domains of ComQol.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'While life satisfaction is commonly measured as an aggregate of individual life domains, the characterisation of such domains is uncertain. This study attempts to group 173 different domains names derived from the literature under seven headings as used by the Comprehensive Quality of Life Scale (ComQol). It was found that 68% could be classified in this way. Moreover, due to the repeated use of some domain names, the ComQol classification included 83% of the total reported data. The ComQol domain data did not differ from single-item global measures of life satisfaction and the within-study variance was lower using the ComQol rather than the original domains. A hierarchy of domain satisfaction was found which was dominated by the domain of intimacy. The other ComQol domains were quite tightly clustered within a range of 1.08 standard deviations. No difference was found between normative data and data gathered from people with a chronic medical condition, but people selected on psychiatric criteria had a lower life quality, most particularly in the domain of intimacy. It is concluded that life satisfaction, and therefore subjective well-being, can be economically and validly measured through the seven ComQol domains.', u'attribution': u''}]}

Wilson\'s (1967) review of the area of subjective well-being (SWB) advanced several conclusions regarding those who report high levels of "happiness." A number of his conclusions have been overturned: youth and modest aspirations no longer are seen as prerequisites of SWB. E. Diener\'s (1984) review placed greater emphasis on theories that stressed psychological factors. In the current article, the authors review current evidence for Wilson\'s conclusions and discuss modern theories of SWB that stress dispositional influences, adaptation, goals, and coping strategies. The next steps in the evolution of the field are to comprehend the interaction of psychological factors with life circumstances in producing SWB, to understand the causal pathways leading to happiness, understand the processes underlying adaptation to events, and develop theories that explain why certain variables differentially influence the different components of SWB (life satisfaction, pleasant affect, and unpleasant affect).', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 [275] W. Wilson\'s (1967) review of the area of subjective well-being (SWB) advanced several conclusions regarding those who report high levels of "happiness." A number of his conclusions have been overturned: youth and modest aspirations no longer are seen as prerequisites of SWB. [42] E. Diener\'s (1984) review placed greater emphasis on theories that stressed psychological factors. In the current article, the authors review current evidence for Wilson\'s conclusions and discuss modern theories of SWB that stress dispositional influences, adaptation, goals, and coping strategies. The next steps in the evolution of the field are to comprehend the interaction of psychological factors with life circumstances in producing SWB, to understand the causal pathways leading to happiness, understand the processes underlying adaptation to events, and develop theories that explain why certain variables differentially influence the different components of SWB (life satisfaction, pleasant affect, and unpleasant affect).', u'attribution': u''}]}

It has to be distinguished from policy, professional, and critical sociologies. Together these four interdependent sociologies enter into relations of domination and subordination, forming a disciplinary division of labor that varies among academic institutions as well as over time, both within and between nations. Personality was found to be equally predictive of life satisfaction, happiness, and positive affect, but significantly less predictive of negative affect. The traits most closely associated with SWB were repressive-defensiveness, trust, emotional stability, locus of control-chance, desire for control, hardiness, positive affectivity, private collective self-esteem, and tension. When personality traits were grouped according to the Big Five factors, Neuroticism was the strongest predictor of life satisfaction, happiness, and negative affect. Reidel Publishing Company', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0303-8300&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'267'], u'eissns': [u'1573-0921'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'2'], u'issns': [u'0303-8300'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"There was no change in the distribution of satisfaction with the standard of living among Detroit area wives between 1955 and 1971, although current-dollar median family income more than doubled and constant-dollar income increased by forty per cent. Cross-sectional variation in satisfaction is, however, related to income and, in particular, to relative position in the income distribution. Whereas regressions of satisfaction on income in current or constant dollars, or the logarithm thereof, suggest that at the same income there was less satisfaction in 1971 than in 1955, there is no significant year effect in the equation using the income-position variable. Easterlin's thesis that rising levels of income do not produce rises in the average subjective estimate of welfare is supported. The thesis raises difficult questions for students of subjective social indicators.", u'attribution': u''}]}

progress of well-being measurement efforts. The accumulated findings on this remarkably quick instrument, show good reliability, exceptional stability, and a record of convergent, construct, and discriminative validity unparalleled in the field. Because of this, the HM is offered as a potential touchstone of measurement consistency in a field which generally lacks it.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'Eighteen years of research using the Happiness Measures (Wessman, A. E., & Ricks, D. F., Mood and Personality, New York: Holt, Rinehart, & Winston, 1966) are reviewed in relation to the general progress of well-being measurement efforts. The accumulated findings on this remarkably quick instrument show good reliability, exceptional stability, & a record of convergent, construct, & discriminative validity unparalleled in the field. Because of this, the Happiness Measures are offered as a potential touchstone of measurement consistency in a field that generally lacks it. 3 Tables, 1 Appendix, 80 References. HA', u'attribution': u'Social Services Abstracts'}]}

u'start_pages': [u'1'], u'eissns': [u'1573-0921'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Enrichment Source', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'55'], u'databases': [{u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/socscijournals/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'M2R', u'source_types': [u'Aggregation Database'], u'name': u'ProQuest Social Science Journals', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0303-8300'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'A number of governments and public policy institutes have developed "Quality of Life Indexes" - statistics that attempt to measure the quality of life for entire states or regions. We develop 14 criteria for determining the validity and usefulness of such QOL indexes to public policy. We then review 22 of the most-used QOL indexes from around the world. We conclude that many of the indexes are successful in that they are reliable, have established time series measures, and can be disaggregated to study subpopulations. However, many fall short in four areas: (1) indexes vary greatly in their coverage and definitions of domains of QOL, (2) none of the indexes distinguish among the concepts of input, throughput, and output that are used by public policy analysts, (3) they fail to show how QOL outputs are sensitive to public policy inputs, and (4) none have examined convergent validity against each other. We conclude that many of these indexes are potentially very useful for public policy and recommend research to further improve them.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'A number of governments and public policy institutes have developed \u201cQuality of Life Indexes\u201d \u2013 statistics that attempt to measure the quality of life for entire states or regions. We develop 14 criteria for determining the validity and usefulness of such QOL indexes to public policy. We then review 22 of the most-used QOL indexes from around the world. We conclude that many of the indexes are successful in that they are reliable, have established time series measures, and can be disaggregated to study subpopulations. However, many fall short in four areas: (1) indexes vary greatly in their coverage and definitions of domains of QOL, (2) none of the indexes distinguish among the concepts of input, throughput, and output that are used by public policy analysts, (3) they fail to show how QOL outputs are sensitive to public policy inputs, and (4) none have examined convergent validity against each other. We conclude that many of these indexes are potentially very useful for public policy and recommend research to further improve them.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 A number of governments and public policy institutes have developed "Quality of Life Indexes"--statistics that attempt to measure the quality of life for entire states or regions. Hagerty et al develop 14 criteria for determining the validity and usefulness of such QOL indexes to public policy.', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Health Management'}]}

u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0303-8300&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'23'], u'eissns': [u'1573-0921'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'26'], u'issns': [u'0303-8300'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'A life satisfaction measure is developed in this paper drawn from a judgment-type theory. This measure is based on the theoretical notion of life satisfaction being a function of a comparison between perceived life accomplishments and a set of evoked standards. These standards are classified as to their derivative sources (e.g., the life accomplishments of relatives, friends, associates, past experience, self-concept of strengths and weaknesses, and average person in a similar position) and different forms (e.g., standards based on ideal, expected, deserved, minimum tolerable, and predicted outcomes). Two studies were conducted on the elderly to ascertain the reliability and validity of the life satisfaction measure. The measure was found to be internally consistent and possessing construct validity correlations through high and positive correlations with the Delighted-Terrible Life Satisfaction Scale; through significant and positive correlations with cognitive age, income, employment, education, marital status, social contact, activity, religiosity, morale, television viewership, and self-rated health; and through nonsignificant correlations with chronological age, gender, and parenthood.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 A life satisfaction measure is developed drawn from a judgment-type theory. The measure is based on the theoretical notion of life satisfaction being a function of a comparison between perceived life accomplishments and a set of evoked standards.', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Health Management'}]}

Reidel Publishing Company', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0303-8300&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'385'], u'eissns': [u'1573-0921'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Index Database', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'8'], u'databases': [{u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/socialservices/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'7U3', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Social Services Abstracts', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0303-8300'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'The recent literature on satisfaction & happiness is reviewed, & plausible future steps in the research field are identified, along with suggestions to facilitate these steps. Using partial r techniques, substantial levels of covariation are found among the variables used in predictions of satisfaction & happiness with life as a whole from satisfaction with specific domains (eg, family life, health). Path analysis reveals confirmation in a dozen domains for a model that has satisfaction as a function of comparisons with previous best experience & the status of average people. Using discriminant analysis, satisfaction with family life is found to be a powerful & predominant discriminator among three groups: frustrated (dissatisfied & unhappy); resigned (satisfied & unhappy); & achievers (satisfied & happy). 15 Exhibits. Modified HA.', u'attribution': u'Social Services Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'I review the recent literature on satisfaction and happiness, identify some plausible next steps to take at the frontiers of the research field and offer some suggestions to facilitate those steps. Using partial correlation techniques, substantial levels of covariation are found among the variables that are used in predictions of satisfaction and happiness with life as a whole from satisfaction with specific domains (e.g. family life, health). Using path analysis, confirmation is found in a dozen domains for a model which has satisfaction as a function of a perceived goal-achievement gap, and the latter as a function of comparisons with previous best experience and the status of average folks. Using discriminant analysis, satisfaction with family life is found to be a powerful and predominant discriminator among three groups, identified as Frustrated (dissatisfied and unhappy), Resigned (satisfied and unhappy) and Achievers (satisfied and happy).', u'attribution': u''}]}

Reidel Publishing Company', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0303-8300&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'347'], u'eissns': [u'1573-0921'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Index Database', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'16'], u'databases': [{u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/socialservices/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'7U3', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Social Services Abstracts', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0303-8300'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'An account is presented of multiple disrepancies theory (MDT), which explains net satisfaction as a function of perceived discrepancies between what individuals have & various criteria, most of which in turn are functions of objectively measurable discrepancies. The historical antecedents of MDT are reviewed. Questionnaire data from a convenience sample of 683 U of Guelph (Ontario) students are utilized to assess its strength in accounting for happiness & satisfaction. MDT explains 49% of variance in happiness, 53% in global satisfaction, & 50% in 7 of 12 domains of satisfaction, including: health, finances, family, job, friendships, housing, area, recreation, religion, self-esteem, transportation, & education. 27 Tables, 2 Figures, 2 Appendixes, 90 References. Modified HA', u'attribution': u'Social Services Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'A fairly thorough account of multiple discrepancies theory (MDT) is presented, with a review of its historical antecedents and an examination of its strength in accounting for the happiness (H) and satisfaction (S) of nearly 700 university undergraduates. Basically, MDT asserts that H and S are functions of perceived gaps between what one has and wants, relevant others have, the best one has had in the past, expected to have 3 years ago, expects to have after 5 years, deserves and needs. MDT explained 49% of the variance in H, 53% in global S and 50% or more in 7 out of 12 domain S scores. The domains studied were health, finances, family, job, friendships, housing, area, recreation, religion, self-esteem transportation and education.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'publisher': u'Springer Science & Business Media', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0303-8300&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'101'], u'eissns': [u'1573-0921'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'32'], u'issns': [u'0303-8300'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"ABSTRACT One of the ideological foundations of the modern welfare states is the belief that people can be made happier by providing them with better living conditions. This belief is challenged by the theory that happiness is a fixed 'trait', rather than a variable 'state'. This theory figures both at the individual level and at the societal level. The individual level variant depicts happiness as an aspect of personal character; rooted in inborn temperament or acquired disposition. The societal variant sees happiness as a matter of national character; embedded in shared values and beliefs. Both variants imply that a better society makes no happier people. Happiness can be regarded as a trait if it meets three criteria: 1) temporal stability, 2) cross-situational consistency, and 3) inner causation. This paper checks whether that is, indeed, the case. The theory that happiness is a personal-character-trait is tested in a (meta) analysis of longitudinal studies. The results are: 1) Happiness is quite stable on the short term, but not in the long run, neither relatively nor absoloutely. 2) Happiness is not insensitive to fortune or adversity. 3) Happiness is not entirely built-in: its genetic basis is at best modest and psychological factors explain only part of its variance. The theory that happiness is a national-character-trait is tested in an analysis of differences in average happiness between nations. The results point in the same direction: 1) Though generally fairly stable over the last decades, nation-happiness has changed profoundly in some cases both absolutely and relatively. 2) Average happiness in nations is clearly not independant of living conditions. The better the conditions in a country, the happier its citizens. 3) The differences cannot be explained by a collective outlook on life. It is concluded that happiness is no immutable trait. There is thus still sense in striving for greater happiness for a greater number.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 The theory that happiness is a personal-character-trait is tested in a (meta)analysis of longitudinal studies. The results conclude that happiness is no immutable trait.', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Health Management'}]}

broad spectrum of homeless people. One-hundred-and-eighty-six homeless people from the streets of Calcutta (India), California, and a tent camp in Portland (Oregon) were interviewed, and responded to measures of subjective well-being. They answered questions about life satisfaction, satisfaction with various life domains, and their experience of positive and negative emotions. The mean rating of life satisfaction was slightly negative for both American samples but positive for the pavement dwellers in Calcutta. Satisfaction with self-related domains was positive, whereas satisfaction with material related domains was generally negative. Satisfaction with social domains appears to be the area of largest variation among the groups. We discuss the importance of social factors and basic material needs as they relate to overall subjective well-being of the homeless.
